--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
> The write-up for my phased searching experiments (including some nice 
> graphs) can be found at:
> 
> http://www.cgreen.dsl.pipex.com/phasedsearch.htm

Hey Colin,

I've just now gotten around to reading this write-up thoroughly, and I
thought I'd comment.

In the section describing Blended Searching you say:

"Subtractive mutations help keep the complexity of a population down,
however, in a blended search experiment described later the downward
pressure on complexity exerted by subtractive mutations was found to
be very light."

This is strange.  Your mutation rates were:

add neuron: 0.001
add connection: 0.01
remove neuron: 0.003
remove connection: 0.03

Is this correct?  Your remove topology mutation rates were triple your
additive ones?  Are you sure everything is working correctly?  If so,
how do you account for the fact that your blended run complexity
increased at nearly the same rate as the complexifying runs?  This
doesn't seem right.

Also, it seems very strange to me that the fitness of the evolving
populations in both complexifying and blended NEAT *decrease* over the
run.  You speculate that this has to do with speciation culling, I
believe, but there is either something very wrong with the algorithm
as implemented or something extremely peculiar about your domain if
NEAT is evolving progressively *worse* individuals.

Derek
